Advanced Biological Sciences (part-time) MRes 2024-25

INFORMATICS FOR LIFE SCIENCES

Continuing Professional Development
No
Maximum Places
55
HESA Cost Centres
Biosciences
Rationale
This module covers a broad range of topics in bioinformatics. However, students' feedback indicates that some topics should be covered in more depth allowing a better understanding of the subject. One of the module member of staff, teaching 'Modelling Metabolic Pathways', has retired. Therefore, we propose to lose the topic covered by the staff allowing the expansion of the 'Population Ecology' topic giving the students a more in-depth knowledge of modelling dynamic processes. As a consequence, assessment 5 will also be removed, as it currently covers the 'Modelling Metabolic Pathways' topic.
Blurb
Overview
Biologists and clinicians are increasingly making use of complex genomic data sets to understand fundamental biological processes, and to reconstruct the history of organisms and disease outbreaks. The aim of this course is to equip students with a broad understanding of these kinds of data and their analyses, and to develop insight into how these methods can be applied to answer biological and medical questions.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The primary teaching will be done through workshops, which will provide basic background knowledge in the topic and types of analyses, coupled with practical exercises involving analyses of example data sets. Lectures will provide an in-depth, research-connected teaching background to selected topics.

The module will be assessed via three assessments that allow students to demonstrate their understanding of the tools used in workshops and interpretation of results. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning Environment. Following assessments, there are optional feedback tutorial sessions to offer students additional feedback on their assessed work.
Educational Aims
To provide a broad overview of the use of informatics in the biological sciences, to give students a theoretical and technical grounding in a range of application areas including bioinformatics-related topics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Bioinformatics is a key skill needed in many research settings. This module gives students a theoretical and technical grounding in a range of application areas including bioinformatics-related topics such as sequence analysis, phylogenetics, and the modelling of proteins, and others. While lectures are provided on core topics, there is a strong emphasis on practical exercises to demonstrate the application of common tools and data sources in these contexts. Teaching is delivered in the form of a weekly lecture and workshops. Students will be given guided reading and online activities to support their learning. The module will be assessed by three data analysis continuous assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Introductory biology review: Students will be presented with a brief introduction of some of the aspects of biology required for the understanding of this module. Topics may include: transcription and translation, protein structures, protein evolution, single nucleotide polymorphism and allele frequencies.

Specific informatic analyses may include:
• Use of common databases important to biologists;
• BLAST (Basic Local Alignment Search Tool);
• Sequence alignment: the use different multiple sequence alignment methods and programs and analysis of sequences;
• Genome sequences analysis;
• Use of phylogenetic and evolutionary tools for sequence data;
• Protein modelling: how to model a protein structure based on homology modelling, from the determination of protein domains to its presentation using appropriate software;
• Next generation sequence analyses such as differential expression of RNAseq data.

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be delivered using lectures that introduce the theory and background to bioinformatic topics and tools followed by practical computer workshops that allow students to cement learning of theory while developing practical skills in the application of bioinformatic approaches. The Liverpool Curriculum Framework is at the centre of this module. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching. This module contributes to a Programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences and based on consultations with employers on what skills they would like graduates to have, promoting the employability of graduates. The teaching approach emphasises active learning and practical exercises, providing students with the opportunity to increase their digital fluency. Finally, student confidence will be developed through taking part in group discussions during workshops. Tutorial feedback sessions for students to reflect on and receive feedback for summative assessment will be available. Assessments will use the tools used in the workshops and real-world data to ensure both authentic assessment and research connected learning. Students will use directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability, IT, and organisational skills.

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Lectures to introduce topics
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Unscheduled hours will be directed reading of material prior to commencement of lectures.

Teaching Method 2 - Practical
Description: Computer practical workshops
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Students will work through a series of exercises following a handout and/or guidance by staff. The activities will be supervised by members of staff.

Teaching Method 3 - Tutorial
Description: Feedback sessions on summative assessments
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Notes: Students will engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Notes applying to all assessments: This is a practical course so assessment principally tests the students' practical skills, as acquired in the workshops. Data analysis refers to the students' ability to choose the correct bioinformatics tools to analyse biological data and to their analysis of the bioinformatics results. Assessments will be released evenly through the module. All assessments will have approximately one-week deadline. They are assessment for learning due to the nature of the module subject (bioinformatics). The assessments should also encourage students' engagement with the practical activities while helping staff to monitor their understanding of the topics. Feedback on assessments will be provided in two ways, electronically (individual feedback) and group discussion (after the individual feedback is released). The latter aims to promote staff/student discussion supporting their learning. If a student fails the module as a whole, (s)he will be given a single opportunity to resit any assessment for which (s)he was awarded a fail mark.

The module will be assessed via three coursework assessments. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

The three assessments consist of data analysis - where students will be tasked with the analysis of data, and interpretation of the results - and/or review, evaluation, and discussion of published literature. The emphasis will not only be on accurately producing or describing the informatic result, but also interpreting the result in the context of the biological question being studied.

Data analysis will encourage students' engagement with the practical activities while helping staff to monitor their understanding of the topics. A key skill is the ability to critically analyse data and convey complex scientific ideas, and discuss and defend these ideas. This assessment will allow students to discuss relevant science to their degree, developing digital fluency and critical thinking skills in line with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Digitally fluent graduates are able to think critically and make balanced judgements about the information they find and use. Reviewing and interpreting published studies will engage students’ critical thinking and help them to see the results of bioinformatic approaches in the bigger picture of biological enquiry. This type of assessment will allow students to develop their academic research skills, critically assessing published work, and interpret the results of bioinformatic analyses.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Students will not revise their previous assessment but will have an opportunity to analyse different data, use the same analyses to address different questions, or critically evaluate different literature. Resits will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

All submitted assessment are anonymous. Pass mark is 50%.
Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

If a student fails the module as a whole, (s)he will be given a single opportunity to resit any assessment for which (s)he was awarded a fail mark.

The module will be assessed via three coursework assessments. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

The three assessments consist of data analysis - where students will be tasked with the analysis of data, and interpretation of the results - and/or review, evaluation, and discussion of published literature. The emphasis will not only be on accurately producing or describing the informatic result, but also interpreting the result in the context of the biological question being studied.

Data analysis will encourage students' engagement with the practical activities while helping staff to monitor their understanding of the topics. A key skill is the ability to critically analyse data and convey complex scientific ideas, and discuss and defend these ideas. This assessment will allow students to discuss relevant science to their degree, developing digital fluency and critical thinking skills in line with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Digitally fluent graduates are able to think critically and make balanced judgements about the information they find and use. Reviewing and interpreting published studies will engage students’ critical thinking and help them to see the results of bioinformatic approaches in the bigger picture of biological enquiry. This type of assessment will allow students to develop their academic research skills, critically assessing published work, and interpret the results of bioinformatic analyses.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Students will not revise their previous assessment but will have an opportunity to analyse different data, use the same analyses to address different questions, or critically evaluate different literature. Resits will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

All submitted assessment are anonymous. Pass mark is 50%.
Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Biosciences
Rationale
This module covers a broad range of topics in bioinformatics. However, students' feedback indicates that some topics should be covered in more depth allowing a better understanding of the subject. One of the module member of staff, teaching 'Modelling Metabolic Pathways', has retired. Therefore, we propose to lose the topic covered by the staff allowing the expansion of the 'Population Ecology' topic giving the students a more in-depth knowledge of modelling dynamic processes. As a consequence, assessment 5 will also be removed, as it currently covers the 'Modelling Metabolic Pathways' topic.
Blurb
Overview
Biologists and clinicians are increasingly making use of complex genomic data sets to understand fundamental biological processes, and to reconstruct the history of organisms and disease outbreaks. The aim of this course is to equip students with a broad understanding of these kinds of data and their analyses, and to develop insight into how these methods can be applied to answer biological and medical questions.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures and workshops. The primary teaching will be done through workshops, which will provide basic background knowledge in the topic and types of analyses, coupled with practical exercises involving analyses of example data sets. Lectures will provide an in-depth, research-connected teaching background to selected topics.

The module will be assessed via three assessments that allow students to demonstrate their understanding of the tools used in workshops and interpretation of results. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning Environment. Following assessments, there are optional feedback tutorial sessions to offer students additional feedback on their assessed work.
Educational Aims
To provide a broad overview of the use of informatics in the biological sciences, to give students a theoretical and technical grounding in a range of application areas including bioinformatics-related topics.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Bioinformatics is a key skill needed in many research settings. This module gives students a theoretical and technical grounding in a range of application areas including bioinformatics-related topics such as sequence analysis, phylogenetics, and the modelling of proteins, and others. While lectures are provided on core topics, there is a strong emphasis on practical exercises to demonstrate the application of common tools and data sources in these contexts. Teaching is delivered in the form of a weekly lecture and workshops. Students will be given guided reading and online activities to support their learning. The module will be assessed by three data analysis continuous assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Introductory biology review: Students will be presented with a brief introduction of some of the aspects of biology required for the understanding of this module. Topics may include: transcription and translation, protein structures, protein evolution, single nucleotide polymorphism and allele frequencies.

Specific informatic analyses may include:
• Use of common databases important to biologists;
• BLAST (Basic Local Alignment Search Tool);
• Sequence alignment: the use different multiple sequence alignment methods and programs and analysis of sequences;
• Genome sequences analysis;
• Use of phylogenetic and evolutionary tools for sequence data;
• Protein modelling: how to model a protein structure based on homology modelling, from the determination of protein domains to its presentation using appropriate software;
• Next generation sequence analyses such as differential expression of RNAseq data.

Emphasis on specific topics may vary according to staff expertise.
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module will be delivered using lectures that introduce the theory and background to bioinformatic topics and tools followed by practical computer workshops that allow students to cement learning of theory while developing practical skills in the application of bioinformatic approaches. The Liverpool Curriculum Framework is at the centre of this module. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching. This module contributes to a Programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences and based on consultations with employers on what skills they would like graduates to have, promoting the employability of graduates. The teaching approach emphasises active learning and practical exercises, providing students with the opportunity to increase their digital fluency. Finally, student confidence will be developed through taking part in group discussions during workshops. Tutorial feedback sessions for students to reflect on and receive feedback for summative assessment will be available. Assessments will use the tools used in the workshops and real-world data to ensure both authentic assessment and research connected learning. Students will use directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability, IT, and organisational skills.

Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: Lectures to introduce topics
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Unscheduled hours will be directed reading of material prior to commencement of lectures.

Teaching Method 2 - Practical
Description: Computer practical workshops
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: Students will work through a series of exercises following a handout and/or guidance by staff. The activities will be supervised by members of staff.

Teaching Method 3 - Tutorial
Description: Feedback sessions on summative assessments
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Notes: Students will engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Notes applying to all assessments: This is a practical course so assessment principally tests the students' practical skills, as acquired in the workshops. Data analysis refers to the students' ability to choose the correct bioinformatics tools to analyse biological data and to their analysis of the bioinformatics results. Assessments will be released evenly through the module. All assessments will have approximately one-week deadline. They are assessment for learning due to the nature of the module subject (bioinformatics). The assessments should also encourage students' engagement with the practical activities while helping staff to monitor their understanding of the topics. Feedback on assessments will be provided in two ways, electronically (individual feedback) and group discussion (after the individual feedback is released). The latter aims to promote staff/student discussion supporting their learning. If a student fails the module as a whole, (s)he will be given a single opportunity to resit any assessment for which (s)he was awarded a fail mark.

The module will be assessed via three coursework assessments. Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

The three assessments consist of data analysis - where students will be tasked with the analysis of data, and interpretation of the results - and/or review, evaluation, and discussion of published literature. The emphasis will not only be on accurately producing or describing the informatic result, but also interpreting the result in the context of the biological question being studied.

Data analysis will encourage students' engagement with the practical activities while helping staff to monitor their understanding of the topics. A key skill is the ability to critically analyse data and convey complex scientific ideas, and discuss and defend these ideas. This assessment will allow students to discuss relevant science to their degree, developing digital fluency and critical thinking skills in line with the Liverpool Curriculum Framework. Digitally fluent graduates are able to think critically and make balanced judgements about the information they find and use. Reviewing and interpreting published studies will engage students’ critical thinking and help them to see the results of bioinformatic approaches in the bigger picture of biological enquiry. This type of assessment will allow students to develop their academic research skills, critically assessing published work, and interpret the results of bioinformatic analyses.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Students will not revise their previous assessment but will have an opportunity to analyse different data, use the same analyses to address different questions, or critically evaluate different literature. Resits will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

All submitted assessment are anonymous. Pass mark is 50%.
Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
